channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: The rising cost of online betting addiction among young people
item.description: In an era when you can bet on almost any sporting event on your phone, it is no surprise that gambling addiction is on the rise. Young men are particularly likely to get in too deep. WBUR's Patrick Madden reports from Massachusetts.
item.content:encoded: In an era when you can bet on almost any sporting event on your phone, it is no surprise that gambling addiction is on the rise. Young men are particularly likely to get in too deep. WBUR's Patrick Madden reports from Massachusetts.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Madden

item.title: 'Gilmore Girls' podcast brings fans together
item.description: From fan festivals to new friendships, 'Gilmore Girls' has built a community beyond the screen, says Lily Tyson, series producer of 'Generation Gilmore Girls' from Connecticut Public Radio.
item.content:encoded: From fan festivals to new friendships, 'Gilmore Girls' has built a community beyond the screen, says Lily Tyson, series producer of 'Generation Gilmore Girls' from Connecticut Public Radio.
item.dc:creator: Mallory Yu

item.title: Bangladesh's first fair vote in years comes with a daunting to-do list
item.description: A landmark election in Bangladesh ended years of disputed polls, and now the winners face pressure to tackle corruption and a battered economy.
item.content:encoded: A landmark election in Bangladesh ended years of disputed polls, and now the winners face pressure to tackle corruption and a battered economy.
item.dc:creator: Diaa Hadid

item.title: A London beat framed by colonial history
item.description: NPR's Lauren Frayer arrived in London after years in India, and she's been covering Britain with the legacy of empire in view.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Lauren Frayer arrived in London after years in India, and she's been covering Britain with the legacy of empire in view.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: Big-time hockey is back at the Olympics
item.description: A look at the headliners in hockey at the Winter Olympics.
item.content:encoded: A look at the headliners in hockey at the Winter Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Emily Kwong

item.title: Rubio's words reassure Europe, but tensions remain
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio delivers a keynote speech at the annual Munich Security Conference; European stakeholders are reassured but still wary.
item.content:encoded: U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio delivers a keynote speech at the annual Munich Security Conference; European stakeholders are reassured but still wary.
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly

item.title: Ilia Malinin, U.S. figure skater favored for gold, finishes 8th
item.description: Malinin, undefeated since 2023, stumbled and fell multiple times, landing far off the podium. Mikhail Shaidorov of Kazakhstan won gold in an upset that shocked even himself.
item.content:encoded:
Malinin, undefeated since 2023, stumbled and fell multiple times, landing far off the podium. Mikhail Shaidorov of Kazakhstan won gold in an upset that shocked even himself.

(Image credit: Andreas Rentz)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: What monogamy in the animal world tells us about ourselves
item.description: As Valentine's Day approaches, we take a look at monogamy and its alternatives among animals — including humans.
item.content:encoded: As Valentine's Day approaches, we take a look at monogamy and its alternatives among animals — including humans.
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: Venezuela debates sweeping amnesty for political prisoners
item.description: After the fall of Nicolás Maduro, the Venezuelan regime promise amnesty and reconciliation — but for hundreds still jailed and thousands facing charges, justice remains uncertain.
item.content:encoded:
After the fall of Nicolás Maduro, the Venezuelan regime promise amnesty and reconciliation — but for hundreds still jailed and thousands facing charges, justice remains uncertain.

(Image credit: Ariana Cubillos)
item.dc:creator: John Otis

item.title: View from Ukraine
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks to Chrystia Freeland, former Canadian Deputy Prime Minister and current economic adviser to Ukrainian President Zelenskyy, about Ukraine.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks to Chrystia Freeland, former Canadian Deputy Prime Minister and current economic adviser to Ukrainian President Zelenskyy, about Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zamora
